questions.text: Arrange the events in the development of the thyroid gland in the correct sequence: Fusion with caudal pharyngeal complex Formation of pharyngeal arches Thyroglossal duct formation Tuberculum impar is formed
Which of the following statements on double aortic arch is false?

options.label: D
options.text: Right aortic arch passes in front of the trachea and esophagus

questions.correct_answer: D. Right aortic arch passes in front of the trachea and esophagus
questions.explanation:
Arch Artery

Adult Derivative

First Arch
  • Maxillary artery

Second Arch
  • Stapedial artery
  • External carotid artery

Third Arch
  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery

Fourth Arch
  • Arch of the aorta
  • Right subclavian artery

Sixth Arch
  • Pulmonary arteries
  • Ductus arteriosus (which becomes the ligamentum arteriosum)

questions.text: Which pharyngeal arch primarily contributes to the development of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue?

A 4-year-old child presents with recurrent infections and signs of hypocalcemia. Investigation shows low levels of parathyroid hormone. The physician suspects an embryological defect. Which among the following could be a possible reason?

options.label: A
options.text: Defect in the development of 1st pharyngeal pouch

options.label: B
options.text: Defect in the development of 2nd pharyngeal pouch

options.label: C
options.text: Defect in the development of 3rd pharyngeal pouch

options.label: D
options.text: Defect in the development of 5th pharyngeal pouch

questions.correct_answer: C. Defect in the development of 3rd pharyngeal pouch
questions.explanation:
Pharyngeal arches, clefts and pouches

Pharyngeal arches
  • Pharyngeal arches are key structures in head and neck development, appearing in the fourth and fifth weeks as mesenchymal tissue bars.
  • They resemble gills but do not function as such in humans.
  • Pharyngeal arches are divided by pharyngeal clefts on the outside and pharyngeal pouches on the inside.
  • Pharyngeal pouches develop as outpocketings from the lateral walls of the pharynx and do not connect to the exterior, playing crucial roles in organ development.
  • Each arch incorporates neural crest cells essential for forming facial skeleton components, while mesoderm differentiates into facial and neck musculature.
  • Each arch has its own cranial nerve and artery.

Pharyngeal Pouches
  • Four Pairs (fifth is rudimentary)
  • First Pouch: Forms the middle ear cavity and Eustachian tube, contributes to the tympanic membrane.
  • Second Pouch: Develops into palatine tonsils; remnants persist as the tonsillar fossa.
  • Third Pouch: Dorsal wing becomes the inferior parathyroid gland; ventral wing forms the thymus, migrating to the thorax.
  • Fourth Pouch: Dorsal region forms the superior parathyroid gland; ventral region becomes the ultimobranchial body, integrating into the thyroid.

Pharyngeal Clefts
  • Five-week-old Embryo: Four clefts are present.
  • First Cleft: Does not form the external auditory meatus (EAM); instead, the EAM arises from surface ectoderm invagination. It eventually disappears due to overgrowth by the second arch.
  • Second, Third, and Fourth Clefts: Overgrown by the second arch, they lose exterior contact and may temporarily form the cervical sinus, which ultimately disappears.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles of the first pharyngeal arch are migratory? Mylohyoid Masseter Temporalis Tensor tympani Tensor palati
questions.explanation:
Arch

Nerve of arch

Artery of arch

Skeletal derivatives

Muscles of arch

First

Maxillary (Sensory) and mandibular (Motor and sensory) branches of trigeminal nerve

Maxillary artery
  • Meckel's cartilage
    • Malleus
    • Incus
    • Anterior ligament of malleus
    • Sphenomandibular ligament
  • Mandible
  • Maxilla
  • Zygomatic
  • Palatine
  • Temporal (part)
  • Masseter
  • Temporalis
  • Medial pterygoid
  • Lateral pterygoids
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani, and
  • Tensor palati
 

All are migratory except T. tympani (Option D)

Pharyngeal arch

Muscles

First
  • Masseter
  • Temporalis
  • Medial pterygoid
  • Lateral pterygoids
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani, and
  • Tensor palati

Second
  • Stapedius
  • Stylohyoid
  • Posterior belly of digastric
  • Epicranius
  • Orbicularis oculi
  • Orbicularis oris
  • Zygomaticus
  • Buccinator
  • Nasal muscles
  • Platysma
  • Levator labii superioris, levator labii inferioris
  • Levator anguli oris
  • Auricular muscles

Third

Stylopharyngeus

Fourth
  • Larynx–Cricothyroid
  • Muscles of pharynx
  • Intrinsic muscles of soft palate except tensor palati

Sixth

All intrinsic muscles of larynx except cricothyroid

questions.text: Match the following pharyngeal arch to its corresponding nerve and artery derivatives. Arch Nerve of arch Artery of arch 1) Fourth a) Superior laryngeal nerve (Vagus) i) Arch of aorta ii) Subclavian artery 2) Sixth b) Recurrent laryngeal nerve (vagus) iii) Ductus arteriosus iv) Pulmonary artery
questions.explanation:
Arch

Nerve of arch

Artery of arch

Skeletal derivatives

Muscles of arch

Fourth

Superior laryngeal branch of vagus nerve
  • Arch of aorta (left side)
  • Subclavian artery (right side)
  • Thyroid
  • Cricoid
  • Corniculate
  • Cuneiform
  • Arytenoid
  • Thyrohyoid ligament
  • Epiglottis: From mesodermal core of hypobranchial eminence
  • Larynx: Cricothyroid
  • Muscles of pharynx
  • Intrinsic muscles of soft palate except tensor palati

Sixth

Recurrent laryngeal branch of vagus nerve
  • Ductus arteriosus (left side)
  • Pulmonary artery (right side)

All intrinsic muscles of larynx except cricothyroid

questions.text: Match the pharyngeal arches to the nerves arising from it. Pharyngeal arch Nerve a. First 1. Facial nerve b. Second 2. Glossopharyngeal nerve c. Third 3. Chorda tympani d. Sixth 4. Recurrent laryngeal nerve
questions.explanation:
Pharyngeal Arch

Pretrematic Nerve

Post Trematic Nerve

First

Chorda tympani (branch of facial nerve)

Maxillary (sensory) and mandibular (motor & sensory) branches of trigeminal nerve (CN V)

Second

Possible: Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Facial nerve (CN VII)

Third

Possible: Auricular branch of vagus nerve (CN X)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Fourth

-

Superior laryngeal branch of vagus nerve (CN X)

Sixth

-

Recurrent laryngeal branch of vagus nerve (CN X)

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct pairing of the pharyngeal pouch with its derivative?
questions.explanation:
Pharyngeal Pouch

Derivatives

1st Pharyngeal Pouch
  • Tympanic cavity
  • Auditory tube
  • Inner surface of the eardrum

2nd Pharyngeal Pouch
  • Palatine tonsil
  • Tonsillar fossa

3rd Pharyngeal Pouch
  • Thymus
  • Inferior parathyroid glands

4th Pharyngeal Pouch
  • Superior parathyroid glands
  • Thyroid gland

questions.text: Match the pharyngeal arch with the artery developing from it Pharyngeal arch Artery a. First 1. Hyoid artery b. Second 2. Maxillary artery c. Third 3. Arch of aorta d. Fourth 4. Internal carotid artery
questions.explanation:
Pharyngeal Arch

Artery of Arch

First

Maxillary artery

Second

Hyoid artery, Stapedial artery

Third

Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery

Fourth

Arch of aorta (left side), Subclavian artery (right side)

Sixth

Ductus arteriosus (left side), Pulmonary artery (right side)

questions.text: Which of the following nerves provides general sensation to the area of the tongue marked in blue?
questions.explanation:
Part of Tongue

General Sensation

Taste Sensation

Anterior two-third
  • Trigeminal nerve (V3) (specifically the lingual branch)
  • Chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (CN VII)

Posterior one-third
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Root of the tongue and the area around the epiglottis
  • Vagus nerve (CN X)
  • Vagus nerve (CN X)
